Idiom (Limburgish): dao kriej ich de kriebels van
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: It really annoys or disgusts me
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Ich vin dat hinderlik of irritant
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Regional expression common in Limburg to describe aversion, possibly derived from involuntary physical reaction
First Example Sentence: Als d'n buurman weur begint te zagen euver ziene tuin, dao kriej ich de kriebels van.
Second Example Sentence: Ich höb gister dao een film gezeen — dao kriej ich de kriebels van, zo slecht waor 't.
Third Example Sentence: Zoe'n arrogante houding? Dao kriej ich ech de kriebels van!

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To be very common or widespread, especially in a sudden way
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Possibly related to bad weather or gossip suddenly 'raining down'
First Example Sentence: De klachten waore neet van de lucht op ’t gemeentehuis.
Second Example Sentence: Rumors euver zien ontsjlag waore neet van de lucht.
Third Example Sentence: Met alle verkoujes lately – ’t is neet van de lucht.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To have a grievance to settle with someone
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Ich höb wat te bespreken mit die
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from Dutch idiom; Limburgish variant common in informal discussions
First Example Sentence: Ich höb nog ein appeltje te schille mit dich euver det project.
Second Example Sentence: Zij hubbe ein appeltje te schille van gisteraovend.
Third Example Sentence: Wee ein appeltje te schille höb, gaot best neet laang weurt.

Idiom (Limburgish): kiek de kat oet de boom
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To wait and see before acting
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Widely used Limburgish variant of Dutch expression, common in cautious or shy personalities
First Example Sentence: Ich kiek de kat oet de boom veur ich mich inschrijf.
Second Example Sentence: Ze höb e bitje veurzichtig—kiek de kat oet de boom.
Third Example Sentence: We wachten allemaol nog efkes; kiek de kat oet de boom, zegk.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To be very relaxed and comfortable
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Emphasizes Limburgish cultural value of calm and hospitality
First Example Sentence: Hij zat dao op zien Limburgs gemak mit ’n glaasje wijn.
Second Example Sentence: Veer laote os neet stressen—op os Limburgs gemak!
Third Example Sentence: Ze waor op zien Limburgs gemak in de sjtróat.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Something seems suspicious or not right
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Relates to something ‘smelling off’ — a metaphor across dialects
First Example Sentence: Die offerte? Dao zit ’n luchtje aan.
Second Example Sentence: Ich vertrouw ’m neet—dao zit ech ’n luchtje aan.
Third Example Sentence: Mit die nieuwe aanbesteding? Dao zit ’n luchtje aan.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To be arrogant or full of oneself
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used in Limburg and Belgium to mock boastful behavior
First Example Sentence: Zoe’n dikke nek höbbe—det ken toch neet?
Second Example Sentence: Hij sjproak alsof 'm alles wist. Ein echte dikke nek.
Third Example Sentence: Dao kump ze weer aan, mit zie dikke nek.

Idiom (Limburgish): mit de deur in hoes valle
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To come straight to the point
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Adapted from Dutch idiom; reflects preference for directness in certain settings
First Example Sentence: Laat mich mit de deur in hoes valle: ’t geit neet good.
Second Example Sentence: Ze viel mit de deur in hoes en vroeg direct waor ’t euver ging.
Third Example Sentence: Ich gaon mit de deur in hoes valle—det is ’n ramp.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: It deeply affects or saddens me
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common poetic expression across Germanic dialects
First Example Sentence: Det geit mich aan ’t hart waat d’r is gebeure.
Second Example Sentence: Ze hubbe alles verlore—det geit mich aan ’t hart.
Third Example Sentence: Det verhaol geit mich ech aan ’t hart.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To know something vaguely but not precisely
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Ich höb iets gehoord, meh weet neet presies
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Widespread idiom across Low Countries, associated with misremembering
First Example Sentence: Ich höb de klok haore slaag höbbe, meh neet gewete woa.
Second Example Sentence: Hij heet de klok haore slaag, meh ’t verhaal klop neet hellemal.
Third Example Sentence: Zij hubbe de klok haore slaag, meh ze kalle ouch maar wat.
